formal_notice_unauthorized_entry.title: Notice to Landlord - Unauthorized Entry
formal_notice_unauthorized_entry.template:
[Date]

[Landlord Name]
[Landlord Address]

Dear [Landlord Name],

I am writing to formally notify you that you have entered my rental unit at [Property Address] without providing the required notice as mandated by [State] law.

Specific incidents:
- [Date and time of unauthorized entry]
- [Date and time of unauthorized entry]

According to [State] Residential Landlord and Tenant Act, landlords must provide at least [X] hours written notice before entering a tenant's dwelling, except in cases of emergency.

Your unauthorized entries violate my right to quiet enjoyment of the premises. I request that you:
1. Cease all unauthorized entries immediately
2. Provide proper written notice for any future inspections or repairs
3. Respect my tenant rights as outlined in our lease agreement

Failure to comply may result in legal action. I have documented these violations and will continue to do so.

Sincerely,
[Your Name]
[Date]

uk_unauthorized_entry_complaint.title: Complaint About Unauthorized Entry
uk_unauthorized_entry_complaint.template:
[Date]

[Landlord Name]
[Landlord Address]

Dear [Landlord Name],

I am writing to formally complain about unauthorized entries to my home at [Property Address].

Under the Housing Act 1988 and the terms of my tenancy agreement, I have the right to quiet enjoyment of my home. You are required to give at least 24 hours' notice before entering my property, except in genuine emergencies.

Unauthorized entries occurred on:
- [Date and time]
- [Date and time]

These entries were made without proper notice and without my consent. This constitutes harassment and a breach of my statutory rights.

I require you to:
1. Stop entering my property without proper notice
2. Give at least 24 hours' written notice for any future visits
3. Confirm in writing that you will respect my right to quiet enjoyment

If these unauthorized entries continue, I will report this matter to the local council and consider taking legal action for harassment.

I look forward to your immediate response confirming that you will respect my tenancy rights.

Yours sincerely,
[Your Name]
[Date]

[Date]

[Landlord Name]
[Landlord Address]

Re: Tenancy Deposit Protection - [Property Address]

Dear [Landlord Name],

I am writing regarding my tenancy deposit of Â£[amount] paid on [date] for the above property.

Under the Housing Act 2004, landlords must:
1. Protect deposits in a government-approved scheme within 30 days
2. Provide prescribed information about the protection

I have not received the required information about how my deposit has been protected. Please provide immediately:
- Which deposit protection scheme holds my deposit
- The prescribed information leaflet
- Contact details for the scheme

Failure to protect my deposit properly means:
- You cannot serve a valid Section 21 notice
- I may be entitled to compensation of 1-3 times the deposit amount
- You may face court proceedings

If you have not protected my deposit, please do so immediately and provide the required information within 7 days.

If my deposit was not protected within 30 days of payment, I will apply to the county court for compensation as permitted by law.

Yours sincerely,
[Your Name]
[Date]
